body:
Some comments:
- **BUG 1: (Itemize)**  If you open your notebook with nbviewer [link](http://nbviewer.ipython.org/urls/gist.githubusercontent.com/schlichtanders/e108ed0be80108178af2/raw/4882e7b6c86e0a23f85b1c81a2b3785408e314fb/latex_test.ipynb), you will notice that the itemization works but depends on the used markdown parser. In my tests I got good results if I separate the list from the surrounding paragraphs by a blank line.
- **BUG 2, 3 and 7: (Raw NBConvert cells)** I think you misinterpret the nature of raw NBConvert cells. These cells are **not** verbatim blocks but rather insert the given text _raw_, i.e without any modification, into the target document. Hence, there are of course no line breaks and the math environment works as expected. What you might want is a verbatim block, which you have to add yourself (e.g. at the beginning of the raw NBConvert cell).
- **BUG 4: (Math)** The conversion of the markdown text to latex text is done by pandoc. As shown [here](http://johnmacfarlane.net/pandoc/README.html#math) the issue with an space after the opening $ is well known, see also #5438. It is funny however, that a space before the closing $ work. 
- **BUG 5 and 6: (Backslash)** Pandoc passes "raw latex" commands, i.e words starting with an non-escaped backslash unchanged to the output document, hence you would insert a latex keyword this way. However, this inclusion only works with latex see e.g. #3503. In this sense a simple backslash should not be erased, but rather passed as `\<space>` (non-breaking space) to the tex document.
- **BUG 8: (math environments)** Unfortunately, there is some difference in the notebook and the final latex document due to the different markdown parsers. There have been some issues related to this bug, but as far as I know there is no real solution yet.

Thank you very much for the detailed response. I haven't thought that the
matter is that complex. Now I understand far better why the same code gives
such different results in latex and html.
One last trouble to BUG 4(Math): if I got it right, then the html version
does not use pandoc for parsing the notebook. In the link to the issue,
there something about Marked.js is said... it would be great if you could
explain this difference shortly

>    but rather insert the given text _raw_, i.e without any modification,
>    into the target document. Hence, there are of course no line breaks and the

>    block, which you have to add yourself (e.g. at the beginning of the raw

>    -

>    _BUG 4: (Math)_ The conversion of the markdown text to latex text is

>    http://johnmacfarlane.net/pandoc/README.html#math the issue with an
>    space after the opening $ is well known, see also #5438
>    https://github.com/ipython/ipython/issues/5438. It is funny however,

>    _BUG 5 and 6: (Backslash)_ Pandoc passes "raw latex" commands, i.e

>    document, hence you would insert a latex keyword this way. However, this
>    inclusion only works with latex see e.g. #3503
>    https://github.com/ipython/ipython/issues/3503. In this sense a
>    simple backslash should not be erased, but rather passed as <space>

>    _BUG 8: (math environments)_ Unfortunately, there is some difference
>    in the notebook and the final latex document due to the different markdown
>    parsers. There have been some issues related to this bug, but as far as I

> â€”
> Reply to this email directly or view it on GitHub
> https://github.com/ipython/ipython/issues/6466#issuecomment-55554870.

The conversion of markdown to html is currently done by [mistune](https://github.com/lepture/mistune). Before it was [marked.js](https://github.com/chjj/marked) and sometime before [pagedown](https://code.google.com/p/pagedown/wiki/PageDown). There exist a lot of different markdown parsers, all with their individual strengths and weaknesses. I'm not sure if pandoc was once used to convert to html, but it is very likely due to compatibility reasons.
So all in all the result of the nbconversion of a notebook to html is in a steady change :smile:

I notice that nbconvert does not seem to support the standard MathJax equation delimiters `\\[` and `\\]`. For example, the following:

```
\\[Pr(X=x) = \frac{\text{# x outcomes}}{\text{# possible outcomes}}\\]
```

Gets converted to:

```
\textbackslash{}{[}Pr(X=x) =
\frac{\text{# x outcomes}}{\text{# possible outcomes}}\textbackslash{}{]}
```

Should I only expect the "dollar sign" notation to be supported by nbconvert?
@fonnesbeck No, I think we just need to add handling of the bracket escapes.

Closing as this issue is not in IPython itself and if still problematic and relevant should be opened on the right repository.  This will allow to keep the number of opened issue on the IPython repo under control. 

Feel free to keep commenting or reopen if necessary.

Thanks.
